ticket.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records
ticket.original-body:
Eager loading a nested has_many association with conditions or order on the nested table loads only the first record.
@@@ class AuthorAddress < ActiveRecord::Base has_one :author end
class Author < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :posts belongs_to :author_address end
class Post < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :author end @@@
@@@ author_address = AuthorAddress.find(1, :include => {:author => :posts}, :order => "authors.id") @@@
Using an order or conditions clause on a different table than the base one uses legacy SQL (LEFT OUTER JOIN) to load, but it incorrectly (eagerly) loads posts. Only one, of the many posts, is eagerly loaded and unfortunately the association thinks it is fully loaded.
Therefore doing something like this:
@@@ author_address.author.posts.length @@@
returns a different answer than this:
@@@ author_address.author.posts.count @@@
(which of course hits the database again to get the correct answer)
Any ideas on where we can look to solve this?
The above code works correctly in Rails 1.2.6!
Attached you'll find failing tests.
Thanks in advance for any help.
ticket.latest-body:

@@@ class AuthorAddress < ActiveRecord::Base has_one :author end
class Author < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :posts belongs_to :author_address end
class Post < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :author end @@@
@@@ author_address = AuthorAddress.find(1, :include => {:author => :posts}, :order => "authors.id") @@@
Using an order or conditions clause on a different table than the base one uses legacy SQL (LEFT OUTER JOIN) to load, but it incorrectly (eagerly) loads posts. Only one, of the many posts, is eagerly loaded and unfortunately the association thinks it is fully loaded.
Therefore doing something like this:
@@@ author_address.author.posts.length @@@
returns a different answer than this:
@@@ author_address.author.posts.count @@@
(which of course hits the database again to get the correct answer)
Any ideas on where we can look to solve this?
The above code works correctly in Rails 1.2.6!
Attached you'll find failing tests.
Thanks in advance for any help.
ticket.original-body-html:
Eager loading a nested has_many association with conditions or order on the nested table loads only the first record.

class AuthorAddress < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :author
end

class Author < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :posts
  belongs_to :author_address
end

class Post < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :author
end

author_address = AuthorAddress.find(1, :include => {:author => :posts}, :order => "authors.id")

Using an order or conditions clause on a different table than the base one uses legacy SQL (LEFT OUTER JOIN) to load, but it incorrectly (eagerly) loads posts. Only one, of the many posts, is eagerly loaded and unfortunately the association thinks it is fully loaded.

Therefore doing something like this:

author_address.author.posts.length

returns a different answer than this:

author_address.author.posts.count

(which of course hits the database again to get the correct answer)

Any ideas on where we can look to solve this?

The above code works correctly in Rails 1.2.6!

Attached you'll find failing tests.

Thanks in advance for any help.

class Author < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :posts belongs_to :author_address end
class Post < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :author end @@@
@@@ author_address = AuthorAddress.find(1, :include => {:author => :posts}, :order => "authors.id") @@@
Using an order or conditions clause on a different table than the base one uses legacy SQL (LEFT OUTER JOIN) to load, but it incorrectly (eagerly) loads posts. Only one, of the many posts, is eagerly loaded and unfortunately the association thinks it is fully loaded.
Therefore doing something like this:
@@@ author_address.author.posts.length @@@

version.body-html:
Eager loading a nested has_many association with conditions or order on the nested table loads only the first record.

class AuthorAddress < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :author
end

class Author < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :posts
  belongs_to :author_address
end

class Post < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :author
end

author_address = AuthorAddress.find(1, :include => {:author => :posts}, :order => "authors.id")

Using an order or conditions clause on a different table than the base one uses legacy SQL (LEFT OUTER JOIN) to load, but it incorrectly (eagerly) loads posts. Only one, of the many posts, is eagerly loaded and unfortunately the association thinks it is fully loaded.

Therefore doing something like this:

author_address.author.posts.length

returns a different answer than this:

author_address.author.posts.count

(which of course hits the database again to get the correct answer)

Any ideas on where we can look to solve this?

Attached you'll find failing tests.

version.tag: active_record eager eagerloading eager_loading has_many has_many_association nested
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body:
Diving in the code of ActiveRecord we traced the problem to ... ActiveRecord::Associations::JoinDependency#construct_association and the following line:
@@@ return if record.instance_variable_defined?("@#{join.reflection.name}") @@@
It appears that this line blocks loading nested has_many associations after the first record of the association has been loaded since the outer has_one association has already been loaded and the instance variable is set. So it loads only one record from the nested association, even tho there are more.
(It's not easy to explain the problem but that's why we attached simple failing tests. Unfortunately that's the best we can do, without help, since the logic is a bit complicated)
This line was committed in: http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/a445cdd8840 for ticket #904. (http://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994-ruby-on-rails/tickets/904)
Jeremy since you signed-off that commit (if that commit is responsible for the bug) can you shed some light please?
version.body-html:
Diving in the code of ActiveRecord we traced the problem to ...
ActiveRecord::Associations::JoinDependency#construct_association and the following line:

return if record.instance_variable_defined?("@#{join.reflection.name}")

It appears that this line blocks loading nested has_many associations after the first record of the association has been loaded since the outer has_one association has already been loaded and the instance variable is set. So it loads only one record from the nested association, even tho there are more.

(It's not easy to explain the problem but that's why we attached simple failing tests. Unfortunately that's the best we can do, without help, since the logic is a bit complicated)

This line was committed in: http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/a445cdd8840 for ticket #904. (http://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994-ruby-on-rails/tickets/904)

Jeremy since you signed-off that commit (if that commit is responsible for the bug) can you shed some light please?

version.body: To ff14 powerleveling be or not to be that is the question...," is uttered by Hamlet in William Shakespeare's famous play Hamlet. He makes this statement when he is trying to decide whether or not to kill himself. I find this quote to be so apropos buy ff14 gil to the situation of making the decision to divorce or not. For facing the end of a marriage, even if you are the cheap ff14 gil one who wants it, is similar ffxiv gold to going through a death. Commonly divorces are messy, sad, buy ffxiv gold hurtful, painful, and sometimes very nasty. If there are children involved, it is even worse. It is by far one of the most difficult experiences one can ff14 power level go through. Therefore, the decision to get a divorce should not be made lightly, in jest, or in a fit of anger. It should only be made once you have tried absolutely everything possible to heal ffxiv power leveling yourself and your marriage. Couples usually end up at the place of facing a divorce cheap final fantasy xiv power leveling because they erroneously believe, "If I get a divorce and get rid of him/her everything will be better." cheap ff14 power leveling Or they may fantasize about the "perfect" spouse and how much happier they would be if could find that perfect one. The problem with ff14 item this thinking is that it is not taking into ffxiv power level account that they are taking themselves with them! You see, until we face ourselves, look at what is really going on within us, and then heal those things, we will continual to end up unhappy. In fact, we will continue to ff14 account blame our unhappiness on our partner, our job, our kids ffxiv gil, or our life. The cheap ffxiv cd key truth is that there is not a person (no matter how great they are and how much they love you), a place, or a thing outside of yourself that will "make" you happy. Happiness is a state of being that can only be "made" ff14 gold by one person? You. When I am working with couples facing divorce, I strongly encourage buy ff14 cd key them to work on themselves within the marriage first before they make this life altering decision. I explain to them that buy ff14 item running away from the marriage or their spouse is not the answer. For if, they do not "deal" with themselves first, they will end up picking the same ff14 item type of partner and end up in the cheap ffxiv item same position down the road. Once this has been done- meaning each person ffxiv cd key has worked on themselves and then the marriage?if the couple decides and knows 100% that there is no way possible their marriage can final fantasy xiv cd key work, it is time to make that decision. At this juncture, we focus on ending the marriage with dignity, respect, and ffxiv cd key honor. We address and go through the process of grieving and healing which is necessary to move forward in a healthy way. If there final fantasy xiv cd key are children involved, we also focus on shifting the marital relationship into an effective and friendly co-parenting relationship so that the children are as protected as much as possible and damaged as little as possible. ff14 item This is incredibly vital for it is more so the children who ffxiv accounts are most negatively affected by the divorce-even ff14 gold if they are not outwardly showing it.

version.body:
Returning the already loaded outer has_one object will allow for its has_many associations to be added to the object. I've add some success with
@@@ ruby return record.instance_variable_get("@#{join.reflection.name}") if record.instance_variable_defined?("@#{join.reflection.name}") @@@
version.body-html:
Returning the already loaded outer has_one object will allow for its has_many associations to be added to the object.
I've add some success with

return record.instance_variable_get("@#{join.reflection.name}") if record.instance_variable_defined?("@#{join.reflection.name}")
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body: I can confirm this issue, pretty big deal to be marked as low priority.
version.body-html: I can confirm this issue, pretty big deal to be marked as low priority.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records
Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body:
Attached is a current patch against 2-3-stable activerecord which includes the failing tests introduced by eric and the solution proposed by nicolas. I have tested the patch using only sqlite3 (but the relevant code is database agnostic anyway).
Yes it is kinda strange that no-one else has seen this bug except us.
+1 to have this applied to 2-3-stable.
version.body-html:
Attached is a current patch against 2-3-stable activerecord which includes the failing tests introduced by eric and the solution proposed by nicolas. I have tested the patch using only sqlite3 (but the relevant code is database agnostic anyway).

Yes it is kinda strange that no-one else has seen this bug except us.

+1 to have this applied to 2-3-stable.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body: So you are only experiencing it with has_one? It is doing the same behavior in rails 3 with a has_many.
version.body-html: So you are only experiencing it with has_one? It is doing the same behavior in rails 3 with a has_many.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body:
A has_one nested with a has_many association triggered the bug for us. We've seen weird counts for eager loaded associations and we started investigating things with eric.
Other association combination might still trigger the bug..
We haven't tested it with rails 3 or edge, tho. The fix seems safe enough to be applied to 2-3-stable.
version.body-html:
A has_one nested with a has_many association triggered the bug for us. We've seen weird counts for eager loaded associations and we started investigating things with eric.

Other association combination might still trigger the bug..

We haven't tested it with rails 3 or edge, tho. The fix seems safe enough to be applied to 2-3-stable.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body:
a has_one nested with an has_many and an order or a condition triggers the bug for me. I'm seeing that bug in rails 3.0.3 as well.
the way I understand it is that construct_association must return the association for the nested associations to be loaded. In the case of has_many, the association is always returned so the nested associations can be loaded. the nested are properly associated to their parent since JoinBase.instantiate(row) caches the records it has already seen from the previous rows.
Hope this help.
version.body-html:
a has_one nested with an has_many and an order or a condition triggers the bug for me.
I'm seeing that bug in rails 3.0.3 as well.

the way I understand it is that construct_association must return the association for the nested associations to be loaded.
In the case of has_many, the association is always returned so the nested associations can be loaded.
the nested are properly associated to their parent since JoinBase.instantiate(row) caches the records it has already seen from the previous rows.

Hope this help.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body:
I am experiencing this bug as well in 2.2.2 and 2.3.5
Person has_one Wallet has_many Receipts
Receipt belongs_to Wallet belongs_to Person
Person.find :all, :include=>{:wallet=>receipts}, :conditions => "receipts.status IN ('unpaid','unconverted') AND receipts.ccy = 'EUR'"
Only returns the first record but it should return many
Please up the priority.
version.body-html:
I am experiencing this bug as well in 2.2.2 and 2.3.5

Person has_one Wallet has_many Receipts

Receipt belongs_to Wallet belongs_to Person

Person.find :all, :include=>{:wallet=>receipts}, :conditions => "receipts.status IN ('unpaid','unconverted') AND receipts.ccy = 'EUR'"

Only returns the first record but it should return many

Please up the priority.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body: I just ran into this defect with active_record 3.0.5 as well. The change proposed by Nicolas and Fotos fixes the issue for me as well.
version.body-html: I just ran into this defect with active_record 3.0.5 as well. The change proposed by Nicolas and Fotos fixes the issue for me as well.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body: I created a patch against master with failing tests. I intended to also port the fix proposed by Nicolas and Fotos to master, but that code has changed so much on master that I'm not sure how to fix it yet.
version.body-html: I created a patch against master with failing tests. I intended to also port the fix proposed by Nicolas and Fotos to master, but that code has changed so much on master that I'm not sure how to fix it yet.
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body:
Hello rob g,
I took a quick look at the master, and here is what I believe could fix the issue.
diff --git a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb index 504f252..26911c3 100644 --- a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb +++ b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb @@ -184,7 +184,7 @@ module ActiveRecord
macro = join_part.reflection.macro if macro == :has_one - return if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name) + return record.association(join_part.reflection.name).target if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name) association = join_part.instantiate(row) unless row[join_part.aliased_primary_key].nil? set_target_and_inverse(join_part, association, record) else
the idea is for construct association to return already created 'has_one' association target, so that the children of that target can be loaded and associated with it.
Nicolas
version.body-html:
Hello rob g,

I took a quick look at the master, and here is what I believe could fix the issue.

diff --git a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb
index 504f252..26911c3 100644
--- a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb +++ b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb @@ -184,7 +184,7 @@ module ActiveRecord

     macro = join_part.reflection.macro
     if macro == :has_one

  •    return if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name)

  •    return record.association(join_part.reflection.name).target if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name)
   association = join_part.instantiate(row) unless row[join_part.aliased_primary_key].nil?
   set_target_and_inverse(join_part, association, record)
 else

the idea is for construct association to return already created 'has_one' association target, so that the children of that target can be loaded and associated with it.

Nicolas
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records

version.body:
This is the properly formatted diff
@@@ diff diff --git a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb index 504f252..26911c3 100644 --- a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb +++ b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb @@ -184,7 +184,7 @@ module ActiveRecord
macro = join_part.reflection.macro if macro == :has_one - return if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name) + return record.association(join_part.reflection.name).target if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name) association = join_part.instantiate(row) unless row[join_part.aliased_primary_key].nil? set_target_and_inverse(join_part, association, record) else @@@
version.body-html:
This is the properly formatted diff

diff --git a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb
index 504f252..26911c3 100644
--- a/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb
+++ b/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/join_dependency.rb
@@ -184,7 +184,7 @@ module ActiveRecord
 
         macro = join_part.reflection.macro
         if macro == :has_one
-          return if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name)
+          return record.association(join_part.reflection.name).target if record.association_cache.key?(join_part.reflection.name)
           association = join_part.instantiate(row) unless row[join_part.aliased_primary_key].nil?
           set_target_and_inverse(join_part, association, record)
         else
version.title: Eager loading a nested association with conditions or order eager loads the wrong associated records
